text: [Music]
paul welcome and thank you so much for
making the time to be with us today and
share your journey on cloud
transformation at Marsh Mlennon i wanted
to uh kick off by asking you about your
cloud transformation uh journey and what
is your strategy around it yeah for sure
it's a pleasure to be here um so we are
I think like a lot of companies trying
to make sure that we're setting up um
our IT infrastructure in a way that's
going to give us the maximum agility in
the long run um manage our costs in the
near term but also just give us the
flexibility to evolve and adapt as our
business needs evolve and we've been
thinking for a while about when to make
the move and when to sort of really
commit to a um cloud first strategy so
the the sort of critical point was
finding um the moment where we could
adopt an approach which was primarily
lift and shift make the economics work
and then push back the modernization
um and the optimization phase until
afterwards and tackle that at our
leisure how did your overall cloud first
strategy align with the business goals
like what were you seeking to achieve as
a business and your overall strategy as
a business and then how did you connect
those dots yeah so we've been on a
journey of really trying to make sure
that the technology organization is set
up to move at the speed the business
wants to move and I think a lot of
companies have struggled with that
historically because so much of what you
want to do um is driven by the speed the
market around you moves and applications
and technology infrastructure are
inherently quite sticky and so it's
often very difficult um especially with
the way we've built applications and run
data centers in the past to be able to
move at the same speed that the business
would like to so it is often ended up
being the rate limiting step on so many
things we wanted to break out of that we
knew we needed to and that's partly
about how we think about how we um
access and and and um and pull
infrastructure together but it's also
about architecturally how we build
applications it's about how we
streamline and simplify the way that we
work internally it's about the skills
that we build throughout the
organization all of those things come
together to try and make us a a more
agile and responsive organization one of
the things we we we talk a lot about is
is the sort of top- down commitment and
ability to move at pace and speed talk
to me a little bit about your your your
timelines and how are you thinking about
actually accelerating on that and how do
you feel about where you are we have a
number of strategic data centers around
the world that we're working through
phase in a phased approach both to
manage the amount of uh change that has
to happen at any point in time but also
to align with lease expireies and manage
the financial aspects of this as well um
so we're one down we're getting close to
the end of the second then we move on to
the third and the fourth is the big one
at the end um but the program has been
built to make sure that we're learning
as we go and in particular that we're
increasing the level of automation that
we have as we go so that when we get to
the big beast at the end um we're we
have a slicker more finely tuned process
our data is in better condition the
amount of the work that can be done in
an automated fashion is increased um and
that builds more confidence to do it so
how is the AI enabled technology
actually helping you on this um
automation journey that you're talking
about both maybe on the migration but
also as as I'm sure you're already
starting to think about modernization
yeah so I mean obviously the the way
that AI is going to play in almost
everything we do is one of the big big
questions at the moment and it's an area
we've been um spending a lot of time on
trying to make sure that our people are
upskilled that we have the capabilities
to help them be as productive as they
can be i think the place where it's
going to start to get really interesting
is post migration because we know that
there's an optimization and a
modernization phase after that that's
going to be pretty valuable where we see
um AI playing as an accelerator of those
things we think it may actually
fundamentally change the business cases
and obviously that's something we're
working closely with AWS on trying to
understand what the potential there is
try and find some projects which are
leading edge projects that can show us
the pathway that we can then scale later
as we get through the rest of the
migration yeah and by the way we're also
you know leveraging this quite a lot now
as well because I think you're right i
think the ability to really refactor now
in a completely different way is
phenomenal i mean a lot of software
companies are rewriting their platforms
on the basis of this technology now you
mentioned AWS thank you so much i mean
we're just super delighted to be working
with you on this i'd love to understand
like what were the what was the primary
reasons that you decide to select us as
your preferred um cloud provider yeah so
we ran through uh as you would imagine
for something of this scale and and uh
and frankly um importance to us a pretty
thorough process of evaluating um a
number of different options what
ultimately made the difference was when
our team sat down with the
representatives of all the different
teams they came away with a
fundamentally different level of
confidence in the people that they had
met about their ability to get us there
you enter these things with a certain
amount of trepidation and a huge part of
it is do these look like the people who
are going to get through this journey
with us um and are going to bring us the
expertise we need and that was the
difference maker and I think that's been
proven to be true as we've gone through
this journey we've had fantastic support
from the team that's been around us now
look you're a 150 year old company um
how do you balance uh maintaining and
you know upholding stability which is
super critical I'm sure uh but at the
same time changing the business and and
innovating at scale well you don't get
to be 150 years old without dealing with
a fair number amount of change along the
way true um and so there is a um in
intrinsic in that history is the ability
to flex and adapt to a world that's
changing around us um from my
perspective when I think about
particularly the technology side of
things the key thing is to be responsive
and flexible we're trying to make sure
that the path to create an idea and get
that idea out somewhere is as short as
possible so those sorts of things I
think are important parts of keeping us
able to respond to a world that's around
us and and Marsh Mlennon is an
organization that is focused on the
management of risk and managing and
thinking about risk is intrinsic to how
we think about things management of
people and the enablement of people is
critical to how the technology
organization thinks of of what it's here
to to do in support of the business and
and strategy u thinking in the long run
about um how those capabilities are
going to underpin how the business
evolves as a whole how are you thinking
about evolving um skills of the teams
here the new talent you bring in as you
embark on your next phase fundamentally
at at our heart we're a people business
and so the capabilities of our people
and the way we develop them are just
absolutely core to our success um if I
think about the journey we're on with
our move to the cloud that's a very
significant transition of people's
skills um requires a different way of
thinking about technology requires
unlearning certain habits and we've
obviously been working with the AWS team
to give people the capabilities um and
the training that they need to do that
um we've built a cloud university
together we're using the skills builder
platform as part of of part of how we're
making sure that there is no excuse
there's no reason that people shouldn't
be able to join us on that journey and
then on the AI side
um you're right the technology is in
some ways quite straightforward but
getting people to really use it at scale
and really bring it into how they do
their work every day is a journey and
the approach that we've taken to that is
get it out there in lowrisk ways and get
the usage uh and then we have an AI
academy that we've built which is about
teaching people how to develop more and
more advanced capabilities you've been a
huge first mover on this u on the
journey of AI transformation and making
this technology available to your teams
and um with Lenai in particular you know
h how are you thinking actually about
scaling this across 90,000 employees so
the lenai tool um we pushed out to
everyone in the firm 18 months ago now
so it's very long established and it's
very much a part of how a lot of people
do their work every day I think we run
at 600,000 queries a week so about 30
million in a year um and uh as I say
we've been building new capabilities
constantly as part of that platform now
as you think about the application of AI
across your various business units what
are one or two areas that you believe
could be quite transformational in terms
of either productivity or uh growth or
customer experience well I think we're
fairly far along this journey so there
are things that are already being
massively impactful i think the general
um employee assistant use case is the
foundational and easiest one to get
after and as I say for us we have our
Leni tool we also have what we call Len
365 embedded in our office suite that
brings those capabilities into the heart
of where people are working every day
advice for other companies and
businesses uh as they either enter the
space or think about you know scaling um
from what you've learned and how they
should think about this the need to
embrace AI is certainly one of them the
need for agility is another um if you're
a global company the need to be able to
work globally with ease and with no
friction is another um I think a lot of
the time the destination is clear and
the question is how do you plot a path
that is the right one and my approach to
this uh which may not be right for
everyone but my approach to this is to
is to be has been to try and retain as
many strategic levers as possible to
provide the capabilities to move at the
speed the business needs to be able to
move at and so that balancing act
of we we know where we need to go but
how do we get there in a way that um
isn't disruptive is additive allows us
to be responsive I I think is something
that's well well worth thinking about
paul I guess one last question um a call
to action for for people listening in
this world of not only cloud first but
AI first um as I say you you you know
what the future is it's it's fairly
obvious and you need to um skate to
where it is uh otherwise it's the worst
thing in the world I think to be running
a technology organization that is behind
the curve and where everyone is trying
to drag you to a place that um that uh
your competitors are getting to or it's
clear you should have been at before um
I think one of one of the things that I
feel most glad about um recently is
taking a bet on AI before I was asked
about it because it was clear it was
coming and um being slightly ahead of
everyone yes is a very is a very much
nicer place to be than being slightly
behind uh all of your um clients and

thank you Paul it was wonderful talking
